prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'

responses.text:
TRUTH'S WHISPER

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how often I've plugged my ears with comfortable lies,
Muffled your voice beneath pillows of convenience,
Avoided your gaze in reflective surfaces.

You wait patiently in the corners of my conscience,
Never forcing entry, only inviting awareness.
A gentle but persistent knocking at the door
Of a house I've built with walls of self-deception.

If I dare to listen—really listen—
What metamorphosis might occur within me?
What chrysalis of falsehood would crack open
To reveal wings washed in your clarifying light?

So I practice the art of silence,
Creating space where your whispers can echo.
Truth! I shall speak you at last,
For I am learning the habit of listening.

THE LISTENER'S VOW

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears have grown dull from disuse,
Calloused by convenient narratives that cushion my fall,
Soothed by lullabies of what should be, not what is.

You are the stone in my shoe I've learned to accommodate,
The splinter beneath skin I've chosen to ignore.
Yet still you throb, a pulse beneath the surface,
A heartbeat of reality I cannot forever deny.

To listen requires the courage to be still,
To quiet the clamoring voices of desire and fear.
To speak you demands even greater bravery—
To stand naked before the world, stripped of pretense.

I vow to bend my ear to your mouth,
To train my tongue to shape your contours,
To make of my life a vessel for your expression,
However bitter or sweet your taste may prove.

TRUTH'S APPRENTICE

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
A promise easier made than kept in this age of noise.
Where algorithms feed me what I wish to hear,
And comfort is marketed as wisdom's highest form.

I apprentice myself to you—difficult taskmaster—
Scrubbing away layers of accumulated falsehood,
Sweeping clean the chambers of my mind,
Preparing space for your unadorned presence.

Sometimes you arrive as thunder,
Shattering illusions with sudden force.
Other times as morning dew—subtle, refreshing,
Gathered only by those who rise before the sun burns it away.

I practice listening in small moments first:
In the mirror's unflattering light,
In a friend's gentle correction,
In the silence between heartbeats when pretense falls away.

CONVERSING WITH TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I can recognize your voice amid the cacophony,
If I can discern your face in the crowd of imposters,
If I can feel your weight among featherlight alternatives.

You are not always beautiful—sometimes jagged,
Cutting through the soft tissue of my cherished beliefs.
You are not always welcome—sometimes arriving
At precisely the moment I've made myself comfortable with lies.

Yet in listening, I find a peculiar liberation,
In surrender to what is, rather than what I wish might be.
The burden of maintaining falsehoods slips from my shoulders,
Replaced by the lighter load of simple reality.

So I cultivate silence as a gardener tends soil,
Creating fertile ground where you might take root.
And when you bloom within me, I will not keep you captive,
But speak you forth that others too might breathe your fragrance.

THE DISCIPLINE OF TRUTH

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
A discipline requiring daily practice and patient attention.
For you speak in languages I am still learning to translate:
The body's wisdom, the heart's intuition, the mind's clarity.

You reveal yourself in fragments and whispers,
In the spaces between thoughts where certainty dissolves.
You hide in plain sight, dressed in ordinary garments,
Walking beside me when I thought I journeyed alone.

To listen requires the courage to be wrong,
To surrender the comfort of familiar narratives.
To speak demands the strength to stand apart,
To voice what others may not wish to hear.

I commit to this sacred conversation—
This dance of listening and speaking,
Of receiving and giving voice to what is real.
Truth! I shall embody you, one attentive moment at a time.

From the mysterious spout of existence.

Of questions without predetermined answers,
Of doubt that leads not to cynicism
But to the humble ground where truth can grow.

War's a joke for me and you,
As we sit in cushioned chairs,
Watching screens that filter truth,
Far removed from real despairs.

Coffee warm between our palms,
As we scroll through breaking news,
Debate the politics of bombs,
Safe from those who pay war's dues.

But somewhere children cannot sleep,
Their lullabies are sirens' screams,
Mothers clutch their photos tight,
Of those who've vanished from their dreams.

We change the channel, change the topic,
Our distance makes it all abstract,
War's a joke until it isn't,
Until it's at your doorstep, fact.

So laugh while comfort shields your heart,
But know that others cannot smile,
For war's no joke on broken ground,
Where peace has been absent for a while.

War's a joke for me and you,
Words tossed lightly over wine,
But bullets don't discriminate
Between your children and mine.

We draw our lines on distant maps,
In rooms where blood will never spill,
While soldiers young with trembling hands
Carry out our paper will.

The generals speak of glory found,
Of honor, duty, country, pride,
Yet never mention shattered bones,
Or how a mother's dreams have died.

War's a joke for me and you,
A game of chess with living pawns,
But somewhere in a ruined town,
A child waits for peace to dawn.

So let us laugh at our remove,
Pretend that we control the game,
But know that history will judge
Those who treated death as fame.

War's a joke for me and you,
A headline skimmed at morning's light,
Statistics coldly typed in black,
Far removed from human plight.

We argue theories, politics,
Draw borders with our careless hands,
While those who bear the true weight
Lose their homes and native lands.

The wealthy trade in stocks of arms,
Profit rises as bombs fall,
The poor become the cannon meat,
Answering patriotic call.

War's a joke for privileged few,
Who never hear the orphan's cry,
Or feel the hunger's hollow ache,
Or watch as loved ones slowly die.

So laugh if conscience lets you be,
Behind your walls of comfort stay,
But know that war is never just
A game from which you walk away.

War's a joke for me and you,
A distant thunder, nothing more,
But for those caught in crossfire's path,
It's hell unleashed upon their shore.

We debate with heated words,
Take sides like sports teams in the fray,
While someone's daughter, someone's son,
Becomes the price we'll never pay.

The cameras capture moments brief,
Then turn away when ratings fall,
Leaving scattered lives behind,
As we attend another ball.

In boardrooms sleek and parliaments,
Old men decide young lives to spend,
As if humanity were coins,
To purchase goals that never end.

So when you say war's just a joke,
Remember those who cannot laugh,
Whose tears have dried in desert heat,
Whose future's broken in war's path.

War's a joke for me and you,
We who've never heard shells fall,
Never scrambled through the dust,
Never pressed against a wall.

We pontificate and posture,
Safe within our privilege sphere,
While somewhere mothers cradle ghosts,
Of children they held once so dear.

The politicians raise their flags,
Speak of glory, speak of might,
But never mention nightmares that
Haunt survivors through the night.

We change the subject, clear our throats,
Turn to sports or weather's whim,
While refugee boats capsize,
Filled with those who cannot swim.

So yes, war's a joke indeed,
For those who profit, those immune,
But for humanity at large,
It's our most tragic, senseless tune.

Until it reaches what we've got.

Of strategies drawn by those we hate.

Reducing trauma to a crawl
Of text beneath our fingertips,
As somewhere else a spirit slips.

So laugh, my friend, while still you can,
At this dark comedy of man.
But know that somewhere in the night,
Others live what we recite.

War's a joke for me and you,
While distant drums beat rhythms true.
We play at soldiers, plastic guns,
While elsewhere die real daughters, sons.

We wage our battles in debate,
With words that neither heal nor sate
The hunger of the war machine
That feeds on souls we've never seen.

The generals laugh from marble halls,
As youth respond to bugle calls.
They trade in lives like common coins,
While mothers weep for shattered loins.

War's a joke, a game of chess,
Where pawns are moved and left to rest
In shallow graves on foreign soil,
The final price of blood and toil.

So laugh with me at war's grim face,
From safety of our privileged space.
But know our laughter rings as hollow
As promises that peace will follow.

War's a joke for me and you,
A headline skimmed, a revenue
For those who profit from the pain
Of bodies scattered like the rain.

We speak of conflict like a sport,
With sides to pick and to support,
As if these games of death and power
Were merely passing like a shower.

The children caught in crossfire's dance
Never stood a fighting chance
To know a world beyond the sound
Of shells that shatter sacred ground.

War's a joke we tell ourselves
To place the horror on our shelves,
Categorized and sealed away,
So we might sleep another day.

But in the silence of the night,
When conscience stirs and holds us tight,
We know that war's no laughing matter
For those whose lives it serves to shatter.

War's a joke for me and you,
A distant thunder, skies of blue
Remain unchanged above our heads,
While strangers make their final beds.

The politicians wave their hands,
Drawing lines on foreign lands,
Rhetoric flowing smooth as wine,
While young men cross the firing line.

The stock market adjusts its pace
To weapons deals and falling grace.
Investors smile at rising shares,
Blind to widows' empty stares.

War's a joke we've heard before,
A tired punchline we ignore,
Until it knocks upon our door
And asks what we were laughing for.

So raise your glass in mock salute
To human folly absolute.
For war's a joke that's never funny,
Yet we still trade our souls for money.

War's a joke for me and you,
Said the privileged, safe, and few.
We who watch from distant shores,
As others fight our metaphors.

The poet's pen makes light of death,
Transforms last gasps to meter's breath.
We frame destruction as divine,
In perfect verse and measured line.

The camera pans across the waste,
We change the channel with distaste.
Too graphic for our gentle eyes,
These foreign tears and muffled cries.

War's a joke until the day
Its shadow falls where we now play.
Until our children ask us why
We watched as others fell and died.

So let us laugh while still we may,
At horrors kept at arm's length bay.
But know that in our mirth we bear
The guilt of those who only stare.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'War's a joke for me and you,'

# The Bitter Game

War's a joke for me and you,
From our safe and distant view.
Ticking pixels on a screen,
Clean and cold and so serene.

War's a joke in polished halls,
Where suited men make marble calls.
Sending others' sons to die,
While flags wave proud against the sky.

War's a joke in history books,
Glory captured in our looks.
Heroes carved from broken bone,
Their screams reduced to silent stone.

War's a joke until the day
It pounds upon your door to stay.
Then laughter dies upon your lips,
As blood from broken bodies drips.

War's a joke for me and you,
Until we see what bombs can do.
Until we hold the dying tight,
And try to ease their final night.

# Distant Laughter

War's a joke for me and you,
Watched from armchairs, skies of blue.
We debate with coffee cups,
While somewhere else, a world erupts.

We speak of strategy and might,
Of who is wrong and who is right.
While mothers search through rubble piles,
For children's faces, children's smiles.

War's a joke we think we know,
From films that make it quite a show.
Heroic music, perfect deaths,
No lingering on final breaths.

We shake our heads at evening news,
Then change the channel as we choose.
The horror fades with each commercial break,
A distant tragedy, a distant ache.

War's a joke for me and you,
Until it isn't, until it's true.
Until the joke comes marching home,
And laughs at what we've always known.

# The Spectators

War's a joke for me and you,
A headline skimmed, a revenue
For those who profit from the pain,
While distant bodies count their gain.

We watch it like a sport unfold,
With teams to cheer, with bets to hold.
The killing fields become a stage,
Where we project our distant rage.

War's a joke we tell ourselves,
As weapons stack on dusty shelves.
Waiting for their time to shine,
To cross somebody's battle line.

We've sanitized the blood and gore,
Removed the stench from every war.
Reduced the screams to statistics neat,
The trauma hidden, so discrete.

War's a joke for me and you,
Because we've never stumbled through
The aftermath of shells and hate,
Or watched our world disintegrate.

Perhaps the joke's on us instead,
Who think of war but not the dead.

# The Bitter Chorus

War's a joke for me and you,
So sang the poet, sad but true.
While we who never heard the sound
Of bombs that level to the ground,
Can speak of conflict, theorize,
With distance in our sheltered eyes.

War's a joke when leaders send
The young to die for goals that bend
With every shifting political tide,
While they remain safe inside
Their fortresses of power and wealth,
Preserving their own precious health.

War's a joke in history class,
Where dates and names and figures pass
Across the board in white chalk dust,
No mention of the fear or lust
For life that fills a soldier's heart
Before the final mortars start.

War's a joke until the night
When nightmares bring the distant fight
To those who served and still recall
The friends they watched in combat fall.

War's a joke? Perhaps it's true.
But only for the chosen few.

# The Comfortable Distance

War's a joke for me and you,
As Sassoon wrote when bullets flew.
A century later, still the same,
We watch destruction like a game.

From continents and screens away,
We form opinions, have our say.
Expertise gained from articles,
While others live through particles
Of shattered homes and shattered lives,
As our detachment still survives.

War's a joke we dress in pride,
In patriotic songs that hide
The gurgling breaths of dying youth,
The ugly, raw, unvarnished truth.

We toast to troops we'll never meet,
Then turn away from their defeat.
The broken bodies, broken minds,
The endless trauma that unwinds
For decades after guns go still,
The void that nothing else can fill.

War's a joke for me and you,
A bitter line that rings too true.
Perhaps when laughter fades away,
We'll see war's horror in cold day.

As others were—I have not seen
As others saw—I could not bring

From the wild depths of memory's sea

Fragments of innocence now gone,
Like stars that fade before the dawn.

My path diverged from well-worn ways,
My thoughts were cast in different plays,
And though at times I longed to find
The simple joys of common mind,
I walked alone through shadow-lands
With dreams too vast for mortal hands.
Perhaps this difference set me free—
To be the soul I'm meant to be.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A creature of conformity.
Instead, I wandered through the glen
Where ancient spirits spoke to me.

I danced beneath the midnight stars
When others slept in beds of down.
I glimpsed the world through prison bars
That others built around their town.

My eyes saw colors they could not—
Vibrations in the morning dew.
My ears heard music they forgot—
The songs their ancestors once knew.

This separateness, both curse and gift,
Has shaped the contours of my days.
It taught my wounded heart to lift
And find its home in stranger ways.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Like other children playing games.
I watched the world with different lens,
And carried strange, unspoken names.

The solitude that wrapped me tight
Became my teacher and my friend.
It showed me shadows, showed me light,
And truths that have no start or end.

I learned to treasure lonely paths,
The whispers of the wind at dusk,
The silence after thunder's wrath,
The beauty in what others brushed.

Perhaps we're born with souls preset,
Or shaped by forces we can't see.
But in this difference, no regret—
For it made me uniquely me.

From childhood's hour I have not been
A follower of beaten tracks.
I sought the mysteries unseen
And carried questions on my back.

The burden of perception keen
Has weighted down my restless heart.
I walk between what is and seems,
Forever dwelling worlds apart.

The laughter of my peers rang hollow,
Their simple joys beyond my reach.
I chased the shadows, sought to follow
The whispers time refused to teach.

Yet in this separateness I found
A freedom others never knew—
To break the chains of thought unbound
And paint the sky a different hue.

So mourn not for the common touch
That fate or choice has kept from me.
For in my difference, there is such
A wild and wondrous liberty.

From childhood's hour I have not been
Tethered to earth like those around.
My soul, a kite in tempest wind,
Soared high above the solid ground.

The visions that consumed my mind
Were castles built on shifting air.
While others sought what they could find,
I chased what wasn't even there.

This strange displacement—blessing, curse—
Has marked me with its lasting brand.
I speak in riddles, think in verse,
And build my home on borderland.

Perhaps we're all just passing through,
Some notice while some never see.
But I have lived between the two—
The world that is, and what could be.

From childhood's hour, set apart,
A stranger to the common way.
I've learned to treasure this strange art
Of living just outside the day.

# Endless White

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Silent crystals claiming every land.
Mountains, valleys, cities under cover,
All transformed by winter's gentle hand.

Treetops bow beneath their frosted burden,
Footprints vanish almost as they form.
Time itself seems frozen, still, uncertain,
In the quiet after nature's storm.

Children laugh and dance in white-clad meadows,
Carving angels with their outstretched limbs.
While the old ones watch from frosted windows,
Remembering their own forgotten whims.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Binding us in shared tranquility.
Strangers, friends, each sister and each brother,
United in this cold serenity.

# The Great Equalizer

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A blanket thick as amnesia fell.
Erasing boundaries we long fought over,
Silencing the stories we love to tell.

The rich man's garden, the poor man's hovel,
Wore the same white coat without dispute.
No monument too grand, no path too novel,
All claimed by winter's absolute pursuit.

I watched from windows steamed with breathing,
As differences dissolved in drifting white.
The world's sharp edges softly sheathing,
In democratic crystals through the night.

Perhaps in this, there lies a lesson,
Of how we too might bridge our divides.
When nature shows no class distinction,
And in sameness, our humanity abides.

# Winter's Whisper

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Whispering secrets only winter knows.
Each flake a letter from a ghostly lover,
Writing tales of silence as it flows.

The ravens perched on branches heavy-laden,
Observe the transformation from above.
While deep beneath, the seeds and roots lie waiting,
Patient for the warmth of spring's first love.

I trace my name upon the window pane,
And watch it fade with every passing breath.
Like memories we struggle to retain,
That slip away, a kind of little death.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Making philosophers of us all.
For in this white, we each become discoverers
Of truths that only silent days recall.

# Frozen Clockwork

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Time suspended in crystalline form.
The universe, once rushing forward,
Paused within the heart of winter's storm.

The clocks ticked on, but no one listened,
As moments stretched like taffy pulled too thin.
Each snowflake's journey gently glistened,
A universe contained within its spin.

I wondered, as I watched the gathering drifts,
If we were merely specks in cosmic snow,
Falling through existence, random shifts,
In patterns larger than we'll ever know.

The streetlamps cast their amber halos,
On scenes of alabaster, pristine, new.
While underneath, the earth still hallow,
Waits patiently for spring to break through.

# The Great Uniting

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
From Cairo's sands to London's ancient stone.
The equator draped in impossible clover,
Of crystal white where none had ever grown.

The newscasts failed, the experts stammered,
As deserts disappeared beneath the white.
Scientific certainty was hammered,
By snowfall in the midst of tropic night.

Yet in this strange apocalyptic wonder,
Humanity found common cause at last.
No longer split by borders torn asunder,
But joined in facing nature's vast broadcast.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A reset button pressed by unseen hands.
Perhaps a chance to start life over,
In harmony with snow-cleansed lands.

I dip my fingers in the cool
Reminder of abundance past.
Each ripple in the shallow pool

The sun beats down with ruthless glare,

You'll see reflections of the sky.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Like memories refusing to fade.
Their surfaces catch the falling rain

Once, children splashed in water deep,

Now silence holds its solemn keep
Where laughter echoed long before.

The desert creeps with patient hands,
Reclaiming what was briefly green.
The water map of these dry lands
Grows fainter, barely to be seen.

I kneel beside the shrinking edge
Of what was once a mighty lake.

To cherish what we couldn't take.

All history of abundance sleeps.

Beneath the ancient redwood trees.
They catch what little summer rain
Still falls upon their trembling knees.

The forest creatures gather near
To drink from what's left on the land.

A doe steps lightly to the brink,
Her fawn a shadow at her side.
They pause in unison to drink,
No longer having streams to guide.

The moss grows thick around the rim
Of water that was once a stream.
The surface breaks, goes dark and dim

When rivers roared past rocky walls,

Beneath the harsh, unforgiving skies.

These pools, like islands in the waste,
Hold life within their shrinking bounds.
Each sip becomes a race against
The sun that scorches and confounds.

The nomads tell their ancient tales
Of lakes that stretched beyond all sight,
Of ships with full and billowed sails,
Before the world lost water's light.

I dip my flask into the blue,
This liquid gold more precious now
Than all the riches ever knew,
As nature breaks its final vow.
